div.p: From Bertha Doughty to Eduard Wehl
RB MSS M number, Library, Royal Botanic Gardens Melbourne.

Transcribed 23 March 1989. Corrected 15 October 1992.
St. Helens, 7 Jan. 1858.

I must ask your advice once more. George is busy with his cattle, it has to be shepherded, & garded at night, so as to get quiet. George comes to dine at 3 o'clock & is out there till 8 pm. — So many people pass here, it is quite a nuisance. Yesterday no less than 16 came & expected to be fed, 6 slept & fed in the hut. — on Xmas day George killed a 5 feet long snake in our dressing room, that was the third killed in there, we have to be always on the lookout. — Only think, Dodds did not come, after I had the rooms ready for them. — Our dear little son is well, he stretches his little hand already for the stockwhip & is so happy when he sees his Papa on horseback & watches him as far as he can see him. I never put him to bed till he is sleepy, when I ask him then: shall Mama put Georgie to bed, he jumps with pleasure, when I have put him down. I go away, he crows a little while & then goes to sleep. He is getting a little curly head. Now I must say good night. God bless us all!
